text: thank you for inviting us to your
barbecue today what a fantastic
gathering of people any excuse to throw
some meat around olive oil no it is it's
great it's um you know what's wonderful
is it's an opportunity to show everybody
across the UK that even the sort of the
people that are unflappable in sporting
responsibilities whether you're a
cricketer whether it's individual sport
or whether it's a team sport it's
important to remind people that in a
weird way they always put more pressure
on themselves and if you taste success
and then can't get yourself back to that
or you're not fed enough or you're not
performing to the right standard you can
end up suffering and that's okay it's
okay to suffer and but as long as you
talk about it it's not it's not weakness
weakness is having a problem of not
recognizing it and not not solving that
problem
everything can be okay but I'd really
regret not ever talking about yeah the
first 28 years of my life
so for these guys it's quite a big deal
for them to come to somewhere like this
and speak on camera and I open up
especially wasn't like urine who's never
opened up before about you know the the
depression of getting to the top then
coming back down and not being to get
back up there the theme that you're
touching on there very much is these are
people who everyone sees is superstars
but they now say they have suffered from
depression or something along those
lines that people wonder about someone
in your position for example and whether
you have had any experiences along those
lines I think the key message here today
is that everyone can suffer from Ammar
for mental health you know whether
you're a member of the royal family
whether you're a soldier whether you're
a sports star whether you're a team
sport individual sport with your white
van driver with your mother father a
child it doesn't really matter
everyone can suffer and I think it
but would be easy to leave it that
because you know all these guys here
everyone's got everyone's got a
different story everyone's got a
different reason but for people to turn
around and go oh you're in that position
therefore you're fine is a completely
ridiculous suggestion I think the
positives of these individuals coming
down and being able to share their own
difficulties with other people in
similar situations I think is the key
thing and that's what we're trying to
work work off here is is once you've got
people in in public roles as such coming
forward and talking about it it should
open the way for everybody else to do it
because as you say it's very easy to
look at someone like really Ferdinand
and go you get paid all the money in the
world you're a successful footballer
you've got God knows how many fast cars
but at the end of the day you know his
wife was snatched snatched from him at
you know a very sort of early process
early stage of his life with her so of
course he's going to suffer doesn't
matter whether he's got an amazing job
or whether he hasn't I would suggest
that if he hadn't might be even harder
for him to come to terms with it but I
think the most important thing is that
everybody everyone is wide differently
but we're all human beings and you can
be as tough as you want on the exterior
and you can be someone who never shows
any emotion but inside there's all sorts
of stuff and I think people in public
roles are a very good way of showing
that tough exterior but at other times
may completely crumble and I think we
need to accept that that's the realities
of life
